repo.description: The most widely used Python to C compiler
repo.name: cython

comment_data.body: I think we should explain why we need `noexcept` here...
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -16,7 +14,7 @@ ctypedef fused my_type:
 
 
 # We declare our plain c function nogil
-cdef my_type clip(my_type a, my_type min_value, my_type max_value) nogil:
+cdef my_type clip(my_type a, my_type min_value, my_type max_value) noexcept nogil:

comment_data.body: Is this just that exception values for fused types are currently handled badly?
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -16,7 +14,7 @@ ctypedef fused my_type:
 
 
 # We declare our plain c function nogil
-cdef my_type clip(my_type a, my_type min_value, my_type max_value) nogil:
+cdef my_type clip(my_type a, my_type min_value, my_type max_value) noexcept nogil:

comment_data.body: No this is because `clip` function is called with GIL released (caused by `prange(nogil=True)`). Without `noexcept` performance warning is raised.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -16,7 +14,7 @@ ctypedef fused my_type:
 
 
 # We declare our plain c function nogil
-cdef my_type clip(my_type a, my_type min_value, my_type max_value) nogil:
+cdef my_type clip(my_type a, my_type min_value, my_type max_value) noexcept nogil:

comment_data.body:
So I suppose the documentation should said something like:

> `noexcept` keyword is needed to avoid performance overhead caused by GIL acquiring during  exception check

I need to figure out correct wording.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -16,7 +14,7 @@ ctypedef fused my_type:
 
 
 # We declare our plain c function nogil
-cdef my_type clip(my_type a, my_type min_value, my_type max_value) nogil:
+cdef my_type clip(my_type a, my_type min_value, my_type max_value) noexcept nogil:

comment_data.body:
That's actually what I meant. It should be possible for Cython to use `-1` as the error value, but it doesn't.

https://github.com/cython/cython/pull/5737 should fix that. But it may not be immediate
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -16,7 +14,7 @@ ctypedef fused my_type:
 
 
 # We declare our plain c function nogil
-cdef my_type clip(my_type a, my_type min_value, my_type max_value) nogil:
+cdef my_type clip(my_type a, my_type min_value, my_type max_value) noexcept nogil:

comment_data.body: I have added a note with the link to the issue.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -16,7 +14,7 @@ ctypedef fused my_type:
 
 
 # We declare our plain c function nogil
-cdef my_type clip(my_type a, my_type min_value, my_type max_value) nogil:
+cdef my_type clip(my_type a, my_type min_value, my_type max_value) noexcept nogil:

comment_data.body:
```suggestion
    Currently, Cython is checking whether there was a raised exception after every call of the function ``clip()``.
    Checking a raised exception requires the GIL to be held which causes overhead inside a `nogil` loop.
    The need to check here is a bug with functions returning a fused type (see :issue:`5586` for the details).
```

I've just made it clear that it applies to fused return types, since generally people would be better using `except -1`.
comment_data.diff_hunk:
@@ -542,7 +638,23 @@ For MSVC (on Windows) you should use ``/openmp`` instead of ``-fopenmp``.
 The GIL must be released (see :ref:`Releasing the GIL <nogil>`), so this is why we
 declare our :func:`clip` function ``nogil``.
 
-.. literalinclude:: ../../examples/userguide/numpy_tutorial/compute_prange.pyx
+.. tabs::
+
+    .. group-tab:: Pure Python
+
+        .. literalinclude:: ../../examples/userguide/numpy_tutorial/compute_prange.py
+            :lines: 3-
+
+    .. group-tab:: Cython
+
+        .. literalinclude:: ../../examples/userguide/numpy_tutorial/compute_prange.pyx
+            :lines: 3-
+
+.. note::
+
+    Currently, Cython is checking whether there was a raised exception after every call of the function ``clip()``. Checking a raised exception requires GIL to be held which causes an overhead (see :issue:`5586` for the details).

commit.message: Migrate numpy section in userguide to pure python mode
